content: Our "dark" theme is pretty light. It would be great to make it darker.

We get periodic requests for this, usually framed as asking for a new, third, darker theme, or for a way to customize the CSS to do it themselves. For example today:

fm schaper said:

Hi. As an "end user", I would like to optimize the zulips standard dark theme to work better with OLED screens, i.e. to use a true black background (plus darker highlights). In the settings (of the desktop app) there is an option to load a custom css. However, there seems to be no documentation available on this - including, if possible, about how to undo any such custom changes.

But also previously:
Mathias Rumbold said:

Alya Abbott any Option that I can develope a dark theme which is like dark as on github as third Option?

And also from Anders and from me:
Anders Kaseorg said:

I’ve never liked how our dark theme design uses a lighter background with darker boxes on top of it. Most dark themes do the opposite.

Greg Price said:

Anders Kaseorg said:

But an overall redesign of the background colors would be a general improvement if done well.

Yeah, I think the two big reasons it'd be good to have dark mode be darker are:

  • to actually fulfill the point of a dark mode: let the screen emit less light (so it's less disturbing in a dark room, and so it potentially consumes less battery);
  • to have better contrast with text.
A dark theme for OLED is a qualitatively different request. An OLED black theme means pure #000000 black, not just darker.

I previously did a quick survey of some other apps' dark modes.

Our "dark" background is #222d39. Even in the message text input where it's somewhat darker, it's #1b242d.

Gmail's is the lightest I found anywhere else, and it is a lot darker: #111111 generally, and as dark as #040404 in some areas (like for read conversations in the main/conversation-list view.)

GitHub's is #0d1117.

Twitter uses true black, #000.
zulip's default dark theme is unusually light

from work on the compose box, see this partial mockup:
https://zulip-compose.vladkorobov.repl.co/
click the little moon in the top right corner to see a dark mode

Ken Clary said:

from work on the compose box, see this partial mockup:
https://zulip-compose.vladkorobov.repl.co/
click the little moon in the top right corner to see a dark mode

That one is pretty light too — the background is #1d1d1d at the far back, and #242424 where the text goes. (Which makes sense as it sounds like that work wasn't intended to focus on this axis of the design.)

Anders Kaseorg schrieb:

A dark theme for OLED is a qualitatively different request. An OLED black theme means pure #000000 black, not just darker.

There are some apps out there that offer an OLED option as an additional alternative to the light/dark choice. That might be a useful addition to to zulip too...

Yeah, it’s hard to make an OLED black theme work as a default dark theme because it can’t convey depth with different gray levels. But it’d be a nice option for certain display technologies and for accessibility (high contrast).
#23724 changes the background in dark mode from hsl(212, 28%, 18% to hsl(0, 0%, 11%

Good to hear! That will be a very nice improvement.

I think that will still be substantially lighter than the dark themes in any of the other apps I looked at above. So I think we'll continue to hear requests to make it darker.
Just to add to a dark(er) design whish list: Wouldn't it be nice to have a per-user per-device setting, e.g. "dark" on the desktop and "black/OLED" on mobile?

the example there is PM type of messages. I was focused on the compose box itself and was afraid that it is might be too dark.

Darkness is easy to check. Tune your screen to minimum light in the dark room and check if you can see things :smile: Than turn it to max anc check if it is painful :smile: The problem with the current zulip background is that it is too blue.

I think the proposed dark theme is better image.png
I don't think we should go darker even by 1% like here image.png but we could... this would require to tune all other colors so they will not be too contrasty
we can make deep dark theme for people who need everything pure black :smile:
I just don't recommend to start from such extreme

A workaround, at least for some android OSes, that gives a darker theme is using the light theme and forcing the dark theme via the system settings. As the light theme seems to be using slightly off-whites forbackground colors, that does not give true black either but a darker theme nonetheless...
